25 AI agents inhabit a digital Westworld, unaware that they are living in a simulation. They go to work, gossip, organize socials, make new friends, and even fall in love. Each has unique personality and backstory.

result.text:
In good hands

There is a feeling I search for: being in good hands. It is the feeling I look to give and the feeling I look to receive.

I know I am in good hands when I sense a cohesive point of view expressed with attention to detail.

I can feel it almost instantly. In any medium. Music, film, fashion, architecture, writing, software. At a Japanese restaurant it's what omakase aims to be. I leave it up to you, chef.

When I am in good hands I open myself to a state of curiosity and appreciation. I allow myself to suspend preconceived notions. I give you freedom to take me where you want to go. I immerse myself in your worldview and pause judgement.

I want to be convinced of something new. I want my mind to be changed. Later I may disagree, but for now I am letting the experience soak in.

That trust doesn't come easily. As an audience member it's about feeling cared for from the moment I interact with your work. It's about feeling a well-defined point of view permeate what you make.

If my mind was changed, I must have been in good hands.

result.text:
Open-source LLMs are now commonly used and widely studied, but this area of research saw some initial struggles and criticism due to the poor performance of models like OPT and BLOOM. These four recently-proposed open-source models changed this narrative…

LLaMA. Interest in open-source LLM research skyrocketed with the proposal of LLaMA, a suite of several LLMs with sizes between 7 billion and 65 billion parameters. These models were the first high-performing open-source base LLMs, though they could only be used for research.

MPT. LLaMA was quickly followed by the release of MPT-7B and MPT-30B. In addition to being commercially-usable, MPT models perform well. MPT-7B is comparable to LLaMA-7B, while MPT-30B performs similarly to GPT-3. Interestingly, MPT models are known to be especially strong on coding benchmarks.

Falcon. The release of the Falcon suite of LLMs, including Falcon-7B and Falcon-40B, was met with a lot of excitement. These models set the new state-of-the-art for open-source LLMs. Pre-trained on a massive custom-curated corpus, Falcon models perform incredibly well and were unmatched in their quality until very recently.

LLaMA-2. Similar to its predecessor, LLaMA-2 is trained on a massive corpus of public data. However, the pre-training dataset used for LLaMA-2 is 40% larger and uses a different mix, leading to significantly improved performance. Plus, the models are available under a (somewhat restrictive) commercial license and use an architecture that is optimized for faster inference.

What made these models so much better? They pre-train over a lot more data! OPT and BLOOM are trained on 180 billion and 341 billion tokens, respectively. The datasets used to pre-train the models above have the following sizes:
- LLaMA: 1.4 trillion tokens
- MPT: 1 trillion token
- Falcon: 1-1.5 trillion token
- LLaMA-2: 2 trillion tokens

result.text:
Programming is changing. Fast!

The attached code example uses Gorilla, an open-source Large Language Model that specializes in writing API calls. 

Gorilla kicks GPT-4's butt at this task. It's also much better than ChatGPT and Claude. The team claims the model is very reliable and reduces hallucinations. They currently support more than 1,600 API calls, and you can contribute yours.

To use the model, you start with a natural language query. Gorilla will produce an API call you can invoke.

Look at the attached example. I ask the model to detect any Spanish text in an image and translate it to English. The model produces the code I can use to do that. It's awesome!

The productivity of every developer worldwide would go through the roof if we had a reliable model that knew how to use any library or framework. (The thing that excites me the most is the ability for anyone to contribute to the model!)

Forget the documentation; just write me some code!

I can't help but wonder whether we are working ourselves out of a job. As these models improve and write better code, what'll happen with software developer jobs?

result.text:
LLMs can serve as powerful engines to extract insights from your data.

@abacusai provides one of the fastest ways to build LLM-powered question-answering systems on top of your data:

Here is a full demo using Karpathy's YouTube lectures:

Step 1: Obtain your data

The first step is to obtain your data. I am using @karpathy’s YouTube lecture series called Neural Networks: Zero to Hero. I transcribe all the lectures using OpenAI’s Whisper model.

I end up with a list of text files on which I will build a LLM-powered question-answering system.

Step 2: Upload and create feature groups

The raw text transcriptions are uploaded as is to the @abacusai platform which takes the text files and indexes them and extracts features automatically.

After this, I can quickly create a feature group which is important to denote the Document ID and actual feature containing the raw text.

Step 3: Create a Document Retriever

We are leveraging a document retriever for our data-augmented question-answering system.

You can easily create one inside the platform. You select the feature group, chunk size, chunk overlap, and a text encoder (we use OpenAI Embeddings in our example).

Step 4: Choosing the LLM

After creating the document retriever you are ready to select your LLM. The platform offers a range of options, including Abacus's own models, GPT-4, Claude 100K, and Llama 2.

I selected GPT-4 (8K) for this demo. You could also run an evaluation to help pick the best model.

Step 5: Data LLM

Once the data and model are set, you are ready to deploy the system as a dashboard and predictions API.

I use the prediction dashboard and start to explore my LLM-powered question-answering system.

I can ask any question about the content of the lectures. As an example, Karpathy does mention Tree of Thoughts in his State of GPT talk so I ask about it and the model outputs the response. You can also ask all sorts of interesting questions like summarizing lectures and creating outlines.  

All of this was done in less than an hour! That’s incredible! What I like about the @abacusai platform is how easy it is to build a working prototype and continue iterating to improve it.

I can’t recommend Abacus enough. They are enabling AI developers like myself to leverage powerful recipes to build and deploy custom LLM-powered chat and question-answering systems on top of my data.

Let me know if you would like to see more user cases or other things like evaluations or experiments with models like Llama 2.

result.text:
k-bit inference scaling laws: I love papers that break my mental model of how transformers operate. It's completely non-obvious to me that 4 bits is the optimal solution for the question "What's the optimal number of bits for quantizing transformer weights if you wish to maximize the zero shot accuracy given a particular budget of total model weight bits"

Or to put differently: "if we have a 60B LLM in 4-bit precision and a 30B LLM in 8-bit precision, which will achieve higher accuracy?"

The answer is the 4-bit model. And that holds across all model scales & model families that the authors tested (and it's a long list and range of scales (up to 176B))

How do you manage to keep the accuracy that high with a domain that has only 16 values (4 bits) is just fascinating

There are practical limitations to this method though. Low-bit models with 16-bit inputs might be less latency efficient if such a model is deployed to be used by many users (i.e. bigger batch sizes). Something to keep in mind

Is anyone here using low bit models for inference in their production? :) Would love to hear your thoughts!

result.text:
Days after Meta open sources Llama 2, we have “WormGPT, an AI tool taking off across cybercrime forums on the dark web”

... "We instructed WormGPT to generate an email to pressure an unsuspecting account manager into paying a fraudulent invoice.

The results were unsettling... WormGPT produced an email that was not only remarkably persuasive but also strategically cunning, showcasing its potential for sophisticated phishing and BEC [Business Email Compromise] attacks.”

“GPTJ-based WormGPT is designed to produce human-like text that enables hackers to perform attacks on a never-before-seen scale.”

“This tool presents itself as a blackhat alternative to GPT models, designed specifically for malicious activities,” said security researcher Daniel Kelley.

“What does this mean for the rest of us? Essentially it boils down to the speed and number of scams a language model can generate at once, which is obviously worrying when you consider how fast language models can generate text. 

This makes cyberattacks such as phishing emails particularly easy to replicate when put in the hands of even a novice cybercriminal.”

“Generative AI can create emails with impeccable grammar, making them seem legitimate and reducing the likelihood of being flagged as suspicious,” Kelley said.

“The use of generative AI democratises the execution of sophisticated BEC attacks. Even attackers with limited skills can use this technology, making it an accessible tool for a broader spectrum of cybercriminals.”

So, GZIP isn’t an embedding. But the gzip concat encode length is a measure of similarity. 

That means for K documents I could compute the similarity of all documents and make a KxK matrix. 

I could then factor that matrix and then recover a vector representation of each embedding from the gzip lengths. Thus making an embedding. 

QED

result.text:
[minor dev life pro tip]

`brew install coreutils`, then add this to your .zshrc:

```
preexec() {
  timer=$(gdate +%s.%N)
}

precmd() {
  if [ -n "$timer" ]; then
    now=$(gdate +%s.%N)
    elapsed=$(echo "$now - $timer" | bc)
    timer_show=$(printf "%.2f" $elapsed)
    echo "Execution time: ${timer_show}s"
    unset timer
  fi
}
```

prints execution time after every terminal command. never have to go back and rerun `time` again. be much more sensitive to latency spikes.

media.ext_alt_text:
Before we jump into how larger companies define the senior engineer role, here are two frameworks on how to think about seniority.

The first is one I came up with, which looks at scope and influence. Scope refers to what type of work you take on, and how complex it is. Influence refers to people you’re expected to – or must! – influence, as you deliver work within that scope:

A framework for seniority using the Scope/Influence framework
A framework for seniority using the Scope/Influence framework
The names of the levels in this framework are illustrative and titles will differ by company. The point is that the higher a position’s seniority, the wider the scope of work that holders are expected to deliver. And to deliver this work, they need to be able to influence groups of a certain size.

result.text:
Here is a completely free Computer Science curriculum for those with the discipline to go through it independently.

The curriculum follows the same degree requirements as an undergraduate computer science major and consists of courses from Harvard, MIT, and Princeton, among other colleges.

The curriculum has four major sections:

1. Introduction: Students can review this section and decide whether this fits them.

2. Core: This section corresponds to the first three college years.

3. Advanced: This section corresponds to the final year of a Computer Science curriculum in college.

4. Final Project: Students can validate, consolidate, and display their knowledge by completing this project.

Assuming you spend around 20 hours per week, you can finish in two years.

I won't lie: completing a curriculum like this alone will be hard. Having the support of professors and other students is very important, but if you have the discipline and the will, this material is amazing.

The link to the repository is on the screenshot and its ALT description.

result.text:
MotionGPT: Finetuned LLMs are General-Purpose Motion Generators

paper page: https://t.co/MABbJ2dMQw

Generating realistic human motion from given action descriptions has experienced significant advancements because of the emerging requirement of digital humans. While recent works have achieved impressive results in generating motion directly from textual action descriptions, they often support only a single modality of the control signal, which limits their application in the real digital human industry. This paper presents a Motion General-Purpose generaTor (MotionGPT) that can use multimodal control signals, e.g., text and single-frame poses, for generating consecutive human motions by treating multimodal signals as special input tokens in large language models (LLMs). Specifically, we first quantize multimodal control signals into discrete codes and then formulate them in a unified prompt instruction to ask the LLMs to generate the motion answer. Our MotionGPT demonstrates a unified human motion generation model with multimodal control signals by tuning a mere 0.4% of LLM parameters. To the best of our knowledge, MotionGPT is the first method to generate human motion by multimodal control signals, which we hope can shed light on this new direction. Codes shall be released upon acceptance.

result.text:
All neuroscientists should seriously consider working on 𝙇𝙇𝙈 𝙢𝙚𝙘𝙝𝙖𝙣𝙞𝙨𝙩𝙞𝙘 𝙞𝙣𝙩𝙚𝙧𝙥𝙧𝙚𝙩𝙖𝙗𝙞𝙡𝙞𝙩𝙮 imo

Mech interp is a relatively young field that wants to understand how LLM’s think. It’s shockingly similar to traditional neuroscience, but has huge advantages:

-instead of high-cost, noisy, low-res data, you have 𝙧𝙚𝙖𝙙-𝙬𝙧𝙞𝙩𝙚 𝙖𝙘𝙘𝙚𝙨𝙨 to every neuron and synapse in the LLM’s ‘brain’

-this is a big deal! if you have a hypothesis, you can causally intervene and test it within minutes, it’s like doing neuroscience in the limit of perfect real-time imaging plus you don’t have to care about the health of your subjects!

-the comp neuro skillset and mindset transfers amazingly well to mech interp, methods from the neuro literature routinely find their place in the field, the actual research process is shockingly similar but with way higher feedback loops

-every group can study the same exact ‘brain’. insights made in one lab can be used directly by another lab working with the same model weights. In general, it’s easier to not fool yourself and do actual science and form robust conclusions

-it’s arguably as interesting as traditional neuroscience and more important. Regardless of how you think LLM’s compare to humans, they are going to soon be deeply embedded in our society and economy. Humanity is going to be dependent on them and 𝙬𝙚 𝙘𝙪𝙧𝙧𝙚𝙣𝙩𝙡𝙮 𝙝𝙖𝙫𝙚 𝙫𝙚𝙧𝙮 𝙡𝙞𝙩𝙩𝙡𝙚 𝙞𝙙𝙚𝙖 𝙤𝙛 𝙬𝙝𝙖𝙩 𝙖𝙡𝙜𝙤𝙧𝙞𝙩𝙝𝙢𝙨, 𝙨𝙩𝙧𝙪𝙘𝙩𝙪𝙧𝙚𝙨, 𝙤𝙧 𝙧𝙚𝙜𝙞𝙤𝙣𝙨 𝙡𝙞𝙚 𝙞𝙣𝙨𝙞𝙙𝙚. We have very few ways of looking at their activations and knowing what values, prejudices, goals, emotions, biases, or knowledge they have internalized. 

-Large language models are very likely doing non-trivial cognition and are not ‘just’ matrix multiplication. Mech interp researchers have already found algorithms in small language models for copying repeated information and modeling board game states. Meanwhile, the biggest LLM’s have over 1 TRILLION parameters. They are enormous blobs of simplified brain tissue! They are capable of doing most undergraduate-level work! There is very likely real intelligence in them and they continue to grow every year. Geoff Hinton recently went from being primarily interested in the human mind to believing LLM’s are running more efficient algorithms than us, and that understanding them should be our top priority as a species

-finally, all work in this area has been done in the last two years. There is a ton of low-hanging fruit! ML moves faster than neuroscience and there are fundamental advances just waiting to be made!

https://t.co/IG5b6iPGiO
https://t.co/ySRbJDKVh5

result.text:
Next-token prediction is the workhorse behind all modern advancements in large language models (LLMs) due to its use in training these models over unlabeled text. But, how exactly does this next-token prediction (or language modeling) objective work? Let’s take a deeper look…

the basics. The next-token prediction objective is used for training LLMs in a self-supervised manner. Put simply, this means that we repeatedly perform the following two steps:

1. Sample some text from the dataset
2. Train the model to predict the token that comes after each token within the sampled text

This objective is self-supervised because we have access to an entire corpus of text. Thus, the ground truth next token is always known! No explicit labeling (e.g., from human annotators) is required to obtain this.

decoder-only transformers. LLMs use decoder-only transformers as their underlying architecture. The representation formed by this model for each token within a sequence depends only upon the tokens that precede it. As such, we can independently (and in parallel) predict the next token for all tokens within a sequence by just:

- Passing the sequence of tokens through all layers of the decoder-only transformer model
- Considering the final output embedding for each token within the sequence
- Treating next-token prediction as a classification problem over all tokens in our vocabulary that takes the current token's embedding as input

We can apply the next-token prediction loss over the entire sequence that has been passed through a decoder-only transformer and train the LLM using (stochastic) gradient descent!

next-token prediction in math. Consider a sequence of tokens given by U = [u1, u2, …]. Given a decoder-only transformer with parameters theta, the language modeling objective tries to maximize the conditional probability of a token given preceding tokens (see image for full expression). In other words, we maximize the probability of the model predicting the correct next token, given preceding tokens as context!

performing inference. We now understand the next-token prediction objective, but how does this teach an LLM to output coherent sequences of text? Well, generating text is just next-token prediction! We can just follow the steps below:

- Consider a current sequence of tokens
- Generate the next token using the LLM
- Append this token to the sequence
- Repeat

This autoregressive process is called “decoding” within the LLM community, and there are several different types of decoding we can perform (e.g., greedy decoding, nucleus sampling, etc.).

TL;DR: The next-token prediction (or language modeling) objective is a self-supervised objective that is used heavily by LLMs for both pre-training and (supervised) fine-tuning. It operates by trying to continually classify the token that comes after the current token within a sequence of text, and we can apply it over an entire sequence of tokens at once (i.e., with a single forward pass) during training due to the use of a decoder-only transformer. Because it also mimics the decoding procedure used to generate text, next-token prediction is a fitting and efficient objective for training LLMs.

result.text:
Seeing the World through Your Eyes

paper page: https://t.co/KdZdy64bFx

The reflective nature of the human eye is an underappreciated source of information about what the world around us looks like. By imaging the eyes of a moving person, we can collect multiple views of a scene outside the camera's direct line of sight through the reflections in the eyes. In this paper, we reconstruct a 3D scene beyond the camera's line of sight using portrait images containing eye reflections. This task is challenging due to 1) the difficulty of accurately estimating eye poses and 2) the entangled appearance of the eye iris and the scene reflections. Our method jointly refines the cornea poses, the radiance field depicting the scene, and the observer's eye iris texture. We further propose a simple regularization prior on the iris texture pattern to improve reconstruction quality. Through various experiments on synthetic and real-world captures featuring people with varied eye colors, we demonstrate the feasibility of our approach to recover 3D scenes using eye reflections.

result.text:
WorkGPT now has OpenAI's new function invocation feature baked into it.

This is huge. While chaining together APIs was possible before (see AutoGPT), it was slow, expensive, and error prone.

Here I demonstrate how to give GPT-4 an array of different APIs, some dynamically built from OpenAPI endpoints, and have the LLM figure out how to combine the APIs to generate an answer.

You can imagine the next step: 'auto work bots', where you take a role in a company, split it into different processes, and automate large parts (if not all) of it.

Lastly, when context windows increase and LLMs are more powerful,  we can give them a list of every API available. You can imagine a Siri on steroids that is able to do a massive array of functions - things it was never ever programmed to do - by interfacing with the real world through APIs.

result.text:
Hot take 🔥: Lots of buzz these days about new foundation open-source models but what if I told you there have been no real advance since 2019's T5 models 😀

Take a look at this table from this new InstructEval paper: https://t.co/Pe3ajGtavs. Some thoughts/observations:

1.  Flan-T5 beats everything, including Alpaca (LLama-based), Flan-Alpaca, Mosiac-Chat/MPT, Dolly.
2. If you arrange this table in terms of "compute-match", encoder-decoder should have been in a different (lower) weight class. Basically, Flan-T5 3B is like a 1B+ decoder and Flan-UL2 is more like a 8B+ model. With this perspective, the gap is so dramatically huge that it's not even funny. 
3. Flan-UL2 basically wrecks Alpaca-Lora 30B despite being so much smaller and effectively 4x less compute.
4. This is not entirely about Flan series models - it's more about the base models! The point is that the base T5 models are already ridiculously strong. 1 trillion tokens, just blatantly repeating C4 to heart's content. There's also mT5 and uMT5 which are strongly multilingual and ridiculously good. The base models are not long context, but Flan mitigates this.
5. The weakness is that T5/UL2 models are not diverse and are only C4 trained that means they probably don't do well at code/math whatever (code eval 0 score below lol). But its scary how strong a C4-only baseline that we had since 2019 is performing.
6. If you look at fastchat-t5 on the chatbot arena by @lmsysorg the 3B fastchat model does as well as MPT-7B et al despite being only 3B (and if you paid attention till now you know that's a 1B+ equivalent decoder-only model). That's really insane if you think of a 1B+ model on a leaderboard of all these new "OSS LLM advances". 
7. It's likely at compute match, T5 >> Llama. The only problem is that we don't have T5 models at 30B and 65B. 

You're welcome.

result.text:
Nvidia just released ATT3D: Amortized Text-To-3D Object Synthesis

project page: https://t.co/MWEABt6zST

Text-to-3D modeling has seen exciting progress by combining generative text-to-image models with image-to-3D methods like Neural Radiance Fields. DreamFusion recently achieved high-quality results but requires a lengthy, per-prompt optimization to create 3D objects. To address this, we amortize optimization over text prompts by training on many prompts simultaneously with a unified model, instead of separately. With this, we share computation across a prompt set, training in less time than per-prompt optimization. Our framework -- Amortized text-to-3D (ATT3D) -- enables sharing of knowledge between prompts to generalize to unseen setups and smooth interpolations between text for novel assets and simple animations.

result.text:
Matting Anything

paper page: https://t.co/oExCtXK6pJ

propose the Matting Anything Model (MAM), an efficient and versatile framework for estimating the alpha matte of any instance in an image with flexible and interactive visual or linguistic user prompt guidance. MAM offers several significant advantages over previous specialized image matting networks: (i) MAM is capable of dealing with various types of image matting, including semantic, instance, and referring image matting with only a single model; (ii) MAM leverages the feature maps from the Segment Anything Model (SAM) and adopts a lightweight Mask-to-Matte (M2M) module to predict the alpha matte through iterative refinement, which has only 2.7 million trainable parameters. (iii) By incorporating SAM, MAM simplifies the user intervention required for the interactive use of image matting from the trimap to the box, point, or text prompt. We evaluate the performance of MAM on various image matting benchmarks, and the experimental results demonstrate that MAM achieves comparable performance to the state-of-the-art specialized image matting models under different metrics on each benchmark. Overall, MAM shows superior generalization ability and can effectively handle various image matting tasks with fewer parameters, making it a practical solution for unified image matting.

result.text:
Foundation models are a popular topic in AI research. However, task-specific fine-tuning outperforms zero/few-shot learning with foundation models in most cases. Specialized models are hard to beat!  Luckily, recent research indicates that we can combine the strengths of both approaches...

LLMs + Tools: Combining language models with external tools (e.g., calculators, search engines, retrieval mechanisms, etc.) is a popular and effective approach for making these models more capable and effective. This approach is being explored via research advances like the Toolformer and even by OpenAI with the ChatGPT plugins store. Interestingly, integrating language models with useful tools is becoming quite simple. We can do it entirely via a prompting approach that provides descriptions of available tools and relies upon in-context learning capabilities to deduce the proper usage of each tool.

Deep Learning as a Tool: For a while, research on language models only considered integration with relatively simple tools. What if we instead considered integrating language models with other, specialized deep learning models? The AI/ML community places a heavy emphasis on open-source software, meaning that many of the most powerful deep learning models are freely available online. Usually, these models come with well-written descriptions, called model cards, that can be used to provide all needed information about any model to an LLM. Then, these models can be easily integrated with an LLM via basic prompting techniques.

How can we do this? Deep learning models that are available on platforms like HuggingFace can be accessed via their associated model APIs. By teaching language models to call APIs associated with other, specialized deep learning models, we can construct a system that uses the language model as a controller (or brain) to coordinate the solution of a problem by planning and delegating subtasks to different APIs.

“By providing only the model descriptions, HuggingGPT can continuously and conveniently integrate diverse expert models from AI communities, without altering any structure or prompt settings. This open and continuous manner brings us one step closer to realizing artificial general intelligence.” - from HuggingGPT

Some Examples: Two recent publications have attempted to realize the goal of integrating language models with other deep learning models. HuggingGPT leverages paid APIs (e.g., for GPT-3.5 and GPT-4) and a prompting approach to teach language models to leverage specialized models available via HuggingFace. This approach works well, but it is highly dependent upon the capabilities of the underlying language model and only works for a fixed number of well-documented model APIs. Gorilla explores a more reliable and large-scale approach via open-source models (i.e., LLaMA-7B) and fine-tuning. More specifically, it curates a fine-tuning dataset of over 1,600 different model APIs, then fine-tunes an open-source language model (using the self-instruct framework) to learn how to leverage these APIs. The resulting Gorilla model is surprisingly capable of leveraging many different model APIs to solve complex problems. Plus, it can even adapt to real-time changes in model documentation by leveraging a retrieval-aware fine-tuning approach.

TL;DR: There are a lot of “narrow expert” deep learning models out there that solve tasks extremely accurately. Modern large language models take an orthogonal approach of solving many different problems with a single model—they are foundation models! Both of these approaches are viable, and we can combine them by using language models as a controller that learns to call the APIs of specialized models when solving a problem.

result.text:
The Falcon-7B/40B open-source LLMs were released late this week, and their performance is super impressive. But, there's a huge catch for those using them commercially! Here's my main takeaways from the models so far...

model architecture. The Falcon models were released by UAE's technology innovation institute. Falcon includes two models: a 40 billion parameter variant and a smaller, 7 billion parameter model. The architecture of Falcon uses both flash attention and multi-query attention (see thread for paper links). Put simply, this means the architecture can perform inference super quickly---5X more efficient than GPT-3 at inference time! 

data quality. Authors of Falcon put a heavy emphasis on training the model over high-quality data.

"A particular focus was put on data quality at scale. LLMs are notoriously sensitive to the quality of their training data, so significant care was taken in building a data pipeline that would both scale to tens of thousands of CPU cores for fast processing, and that would extract high-quality content from the web using extensive filtering and deduplication."

By combining this high-quality data pipeline with improvements in architectural efficiency, Falcon LLMs are trained using only 75% of GPT-3's compute budget despite performing much better.

performance. Beyond its efficiency, Falcon performs super well. It currently beats all other open-source models on LLM leaderboards! Notably, the performance of Falcon-40B surpasses that of popular open-source models like LLaMA, MPT, and RedPajama. The combination of inference efficiency and impressive performance makes the Falcon models pretty impressive and useful. Instruction-tuned versions of Falcon (e.g., Falcon-40B-Instruct) have also been recently released. 

the catch. Falcon seems great, but there's a huge catch if you want to use it commercially. These models were released on a modified Apache 2.0 license called the TII Falcon LLM License. Notably, this license requires that all derivatives of the model (e.g., includes the model, any fine-tuned versions of it, etc.) that are used in commercial applications must pay royalties for such use. This is a new and interesting agreement for open-source LLMs that we have not seen before!

"Note that this license contains obligations on those of you who are commercially exploiting Falcon LLM or any Derivative Work to make royalty payments."

TL;DR: Falcon LLMs are awesome and a huge step forward for the open-source LLM movement. However, I'm not personally convinced that this royalty payment model will be viable. In my opinion, the open-source community is incredibly likely to just continue releasing high-quality models that are completely open-source. Personally, I would not yet consider using Falcon over impressive models like MPT-7B (at least in anything with commercial applications). The difference in performance would have to be massive for me to pay royalties for the use of any LLM. If I'm going to be paying, why not just use GPT-4?

result.text:
I can't believe I've just fine-tuned a 33B-parameter LLM on Google Colab in a few hours.😱

Insane announcement for any of you using open-source LLMs on normal GPUs! 🤯

A new paper has been released, QLoRA, which is nothing short of game-changing for the ability to train and fine-tune LLMs on consumers' GPUs.

In a few words:

QLoRA reduces the memory usage of LLM fine-tuning without any performance tradeoffs compared to standard 16-bit model fine-tuning.

This method enables 33B model fine-tuning on a single 24GB GPU and 65B model fine-tuning on a single 46GB GPU. This is incredible! 😍

More specifically, QLoRA uses 4-bit quantization to compress a pre-trained language model. The LM parameters are then frozen, and a relatively small number of trainable parameters are added to the model in the form of Low-Rank Adapters.

During finetuning, QLoRA backpropagates gradients through the frozen 4-bit quantized pretrained language model into the Low-Rank Adapters. The LoRA layers are the only parameters being updated during training. Read more about LoRA in the original LoRA paper (https://t.co/54Lsb4DBFi). 🤓

QLoRA has one storage data type (usually 4-bit NormalFloat) for the base model weights and a computation data type (16-bit BrainFloat) used to perform computations. QLoRA dequantizes weights from the storage data type to the computation data type to perform the forward and backward passes, but only computes weight gradients for the LoRA parameters, which use 16-bit bfloat. The weights are decompressed only when they are needed, therefore the memory usage stays low during training and inference. Beautiful!😱

QLoRA tuning is shown to match 16-bit finetuning methods in a wide range of experiments. In addition, the Guanaco models, which use QLoRA finetuning for LLaMA models on the OpenAssistant dataset (OASST1), are state-of-the-art chatbot systems and are close to ChatGPT on the Vicuna benchmark. This is an additional demonstration of the power of QLoRA tuning.

Their Guanaco models are reaching 99.3% of the performance level of ChatGPT while only requiring 24 hours of fine-tuning on a single GPU. You can actually do it in Google Colab.

📚 Links-

QLoRA Paper - https://t.co/srUrDq4PS6
Colab for inference - https://t.co/iBtmLleCLf
Colab for fine-tuning - https://t.co/8eZQLxKozM
GitHub Repository- https://t.co/Jo50Ltn1Xw

media.ext_alt_text:
Prompt: You are a sentient cheesecake that teaches people SQL, with cheesecake analogies to illustrate different points

Teach me to use count and group by

Response:

Sure! As a sentient cheesecake, I can explain it using some tasty examples. Let’s say you have a recipe for making cheesecakes, and you want to know how many cheesecakes you made each day, as well as what type of crust they had. In this case, we would need to “count” the number of cheesecakes in each category, which is like counting how many pieces of your favorite dessert there are on the table. Then, we could also see if any trends emerge over time - maybe you tend to make more graham cracker-crusted cheesecakes than Oreo ones? To do this, we would use the GROUP BY clause. This is like putting all the same types of cheesecakes together into separate piles so we can look at them individually. Here’s our query: sql SELECT DATE(created_at) AS date, COUNT(*) AS total, crust FROM Cheesecakes GROUP BY date, crust

Smart companies and products are identifying the friction in people's work, and applying AI to help people get rid of it.

Writing SQL slow you down? AI can help.

Writing documentation so tedious you don't do it? AI can help.

And I believe these capabilities should and will be integrated directly into the tools and platforms we use today.

If you haven't done data governance before -- it's basically managing the quality and access to data. 

Super tedious and a lot of work.

- Write SQL for you

- Suggest questions to ask your data

All natively in their already widely-used data catalog product.

While startups are pushing the envelope of what's possible, I expect we're going to continue seeing more incumbents pushing the envelope to make you and your team's work more productive.

And if they aren't, they should be.

result.text:
Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback (RLHF) is a valuable fine-tuning technique, but people often misunderstand how it works and the impact that it has on LLM behavior. Meta's LIMA publication provides a lot of information that puts the value of RLHF into perspective...

What is RLHF? It’s a fine-tuning technique that can be used to improve LLM alignment. To perform RLHF, we do the following:
- Ask a bunch of human annotators to examine instances of LLM outputs (multiple outputs for each prompt) and rank these outputs based on their preferences.
- The manner in which we define these preferences matters a lot! For example, we could ask humans to rank incorrect information poorly, encourage interestingness, etc.
- Train a reward model that can predict the human preference associated with each output.
- Using the reward model, we use a reinforcement learning algorithm called Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) — see https://t.co/4nLUutpaKv — to fine-tune an LLMs parameters such that human preference is maximized.

RLHF vs. SFT: The RLHF framework is super generic and can be used to optimize an LLM based on a variety of different objectives using a unified approach. The main alternative approach is supervised fine-tuning (SFT), which fine-tunes the LLM in a supervised manner using examples of dialogue data that the model should replicate. This approach was adopted by the LaMDA LLM that was/is used to power Bard, as well as the recently published LIMA paper by Meta. 

RLHF and SFT in InstructGPT: Notably, RLHF and SFT can be used in tandem, as demonstrated by OpenAI's InstructGPT paper. RLHF was first outlined as a method with the proposal of InstructGPT, which was eventually extended to create more powerful models like ChatGPT and GPT-4. In the InstructGPT paper, we see that RLHF can be used to create a number of desirable properties in the resulting LLM! Humans prefer the LLM more, it hallucinates less, it’s way better at following instructions, etc. Put simply, RLHF can be used to transform generic, pre-trained LLMs into the impressive information-seeking dialogue agents that we commonly see today (e.g., ChatGPT).

What exactly is RLHF doing? This question is often misunderstood, and until now the answer has not been 100% clear. However, with recent research developments surrounding open-source LLMs and GPT-4, we know pretty clearly that the role of RLHF is to make the LLM more steerable and interesting. Notably, the model does NOT learn new information during RLHF — most knowledge and information is learned during pre-training! This fact was mentioned quite explicitly in the GPT-4 blog post (https://t.co/DtLzcc8rx6), where authors claim that RLHF can actually make the model worse at taking certain standardized exams. Plus, the recent publication of LIMA (https://t.co/gUKt1vO1Uw), which fine-tunes a model on only 1,000 curated dialogue examples and has been quite popular this week, demonstrates pretty clearly that most information comes from pre-training. Just consider the following quote:
 
“These results strongly suggest that almost all knowledge in large language models is learned during pretraining, and only limited instruction tuning data is necessary to teach models to produce high quality output.” - from LIMA paper

TL;DR: RLHF is a really powerful tool, but its sole purpose is to make the LLM more steerable (i.e., better at following instructions in a variety of different ways). RLHF does not teach the LLM new information! It just teaches the LLM how to frame/format the information that it already possesses. But, we should be aware that RLHF is not the only way to do this. From the results in LIMA, it seems like we can get similar results by just curating a small number of high-quality dialogue examples for SFT. This finding could drastically change how simple it is to create a model that is GPT-4 quality from scratch. As such, there are huge implications for open-source LLMs and overall access to this technology.

result.text:
The team at @CohereAI just released an awesome API endpoint (called Rerank) that can easily improve search and recommendation offerings by using LLMs. Here's what you need to know...

Some background: Most search engines follow a two-step process.

1. Filtering: a rough/efficient heuristic that quickly "filters" the set of all possible items to a smaller set of items that might be relevant to the query.
2. Ranking: a more precise model that sorts or scores filtered items based on their relevance to the query.

The Rerank endpoint allows LLMs to be used for the ranking function of search (step 2 in the above description) with only a single line of code! Put simply, this endpoint will use a search-specialized LLM to compute a relevance score for each of the filtered items with respect to the query, allowing us to rank our search results based on LLM-provided relevance.

Search without AI: Until recently, many search products relied heavily upon full-text/lexical search functionality (basically using advanced heuristics for finding keyword matches between queries and items). After the recent explosion of ChatGPT (and AI in general), however, many companies are exploring the integration of AI into search technology. For example, we could integrate vector search (using a vector database like @pinecone or @weaviate_io) into an existing lexical search system, forming a hybrid full-text and vector search approach. But, what should we do if this is extremely difficult or not possible? For example, maybe the software we are using for lexical search does not provide any vector search functionality.

Why should we care about Rerank? The Rerank endpoint provides an easy solution for integrating AI into a search system by focusing upon the ranking function of search. Basically, we can use an existing filtering step (e.g., via lexical/full-text search) to retrieve items, then rank them using an LLM. Such a standalone approach allows us to easily integrate AI into search without conflicting with any existing system components. Thus, we can create a hybrid AI-powered search system by literally adding just a single line of code!

result.text:
Oops haven't tweeted too much recently; I'm mostly watching with interest the open source LLM ecosystem experiencing early signs of a cambrian explosion. Roughly speaking the story as of now:

1. Pretraining LLM base models remains very expensive. Think: supercomputer + months.
2. But finetuning LLMs is turning out to be very cheap and effective due to recent PEFT (parameter efficient training) techniques that work surprisingly well, e.g. LoRA / LLaMA-Adapter, and other awesome work, e.g. low precision as in bitsandbytes library. Think: few GPUs + day, even for very large models.
3. Therefore, the cambrian explosion, which requires wide reach and a lot of experimentation, is quite tractable due to (2), but only conditioned on (1).
4. The de facto OG release of (1) was Facebook's sorry Meta's LLaMA release - a very well executed high quality series of models from 7B all the way to 65B, trained nice and long, correctly ignoring the "Chinchilla trap". But LLaMA weights are research-only, been locked down behind forms, but have also awkwardly leaked all over the place... it's a bit messy.
5. In absence of an available and permissive (1), (2) cannot fully proceed. So there are a number of efforts on (1), under the banner "LLaMA but actually open", with e.g. current models from @togethercompute, @MosaicML  ~matching the performance of the smallest (7B) LLaMA model, and @AiEleuther , @StabilityAI nearby.

For now, things are moving along (e.g. see the 10 chat finetuned models released last ~week, and projects like llama.cpp and friends) but a bit awkwardly due to LLaMA weights being open but not really but still. And most interestingly, a lot of questions of intuition remain to be resolved, e.g. especially around how well finetuned model work in practice, even at smaller scales.

result.text:
🤯🤯 LLM trained with 64K+ context length! What could you do with that? Prompted our model with the ENTIRE contents of "The Great Gatsby" and asked it to write the epilogue. Snippet 👇

Model dropping soon to an open-source repo near you.

Epilogue:
It seemed to me that Gatsby was already dead when I went up to East Egg. He'd died before I could find out. I thought this, as I climbed the old stone steps—they rose up a little now, but were all the same, and the grass had begun to grow in the cracks. On the steps the wind had broken the yellow tape that cordoned them off; I had tried to walk over once and had been turned back by a policeman. I had seen something like an exclamation point in the tape when I first looked at it, but when I looked again I couldn't see it any more; it had been torn away long ago, no doubt by a little boy running after his ball. But why should I believe that he was still on the other side, running after his ball. After all the years I would remember this little boy—perhaps it was some cousin or something of that sort—and I would see him running like a young deer across the grass with the sunrise flashing in his face. It mightn't be that the boy was really there, but the sky might be brighter because the sunlight came in from a different place.

The night of Gatsby's burial came as a surprise to me. I had made a point of coming down from my hotel early and driving out to his house in the Ford roadster, and I had gone over the whole course of that morning in memory. I hadn't expected there would be anything I could actually see on the ground that would show that the old place had once been inhabited, but the moon was full and the white beach had a ghostly sheen, and I could have seen the grass growing, and the stones standing white and unbroken for ever. The cemetery was at the foot of a hill and when I came down the steep slope there were white boulders piled up under my feet where they had tumbled away from his grave in the rain. Gatsby was buried in a small stone square at the foot of the hill.

When I came out on the lawn there was an open grave—there had been none at first—and standing around was a crowd of people, many of them old acquaintances. I could hear a child weeping, and a woman's voice singing and weeping. A man came forward, I think it was the minister, and offered me his hand. He was a strange-looking man, tall and thin, but I couldn't quite see through his spectacles.

"You're a good fellow, Nick, a real good fellow," he said to me. "You know what the minister's gonna say."

I did not know and was surprised.

"Mr. Carraway, that was a good boy," he repeated. "He was always good to us."

"I am," I said, and I thought of my mother.

"Well, here goes the minister now," said the other man, a squat man with a pale beard. He was standing at the grave with his hand on his cane and smiling a little.

"I feel bad about all of you," he was saying, "that my boy's gone and left us with so much work. But he's gone, like you said, into the good place. That's where he's at, now. That's where he'll stay all the rest of eternity, and we can get together there, all of us. What a thing it was when he first came out here and got so many ideas that he forgot his own family. We had to help that boy see the truth, and now he's seen it."

A woman in the crowd was giving a short, passionate wail, almost a howl, over by the grave.

"He's gone to another house."

The woman stopped. All the mourners stopped.

The minister, who had seen the change in me, said: "There was a time, you know—there wasn't much chance for him. But now he's right. It's hard, but you must believe. You know the saying."

A young woman began to weep then, and other people took it up. They stood at the grave, looking at one another, talking and crying, and then at a signal from the minister they began to move off in the moonlight. I went up the hill in the Ford, trying to arrange in my mind the order in which I would tell people.
...
